title: Lesson 01: Vectors
objectives: Understand the three perspectives on vectors (physics, CS, math)
Perform vector addition geometrically and algebraically

cards.front: What are the three perspectives on vectors?
cards.back:
1. Physics: Arrows in space defined by length and direction (position doesn't matter)
  2. Computer Science: Ordered lists of numbers
  3. Mathematics: Any object where vector addition and scalar multiplication are sensible operations

cards.front: How do you add two vectors geometrically?
cards.back:
Place the second vector's tail at the first vector's tip. Draw a new vector from the first vector's tail to the second vector's tip.

This represents combined movements or steps.

cards.front:
How do you add two vectors algebraically?

\( [x_1, y_1] + [x_2, y_2] = ? \)
cards.back:
\( [x_1 + x_2, y_1 + y_2] \)

Match up terms and add them together.

cards.front: What does scalar multiplication do to a vector?
cards.back:
It stretches, squishes, or reverses the vector.

  • Positive scalars: stretch or compress
  • Negative scalars: flip direction plus stretch/compress

Formula: \( k \cdot [x, y] = [kx, ky] \)

cards.front: What is the origin in a coordinate system?
cards.back: The intersection point of all axes; the starting point for all vectors. In 2D, it's where the x-axis and y-axis meet. All position vectors are drawn from the origin.
